journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A practical approach for analysis of leakage flow characteristics in hydraulic pumps

article-meta.aff: Hydraulic System Engineering Office, Driveline System Engineering Department, JTEKT Corporation, Takahama, Aichi, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Yoshiharu Inaguma, Hydraulic System Engineering Office, Driveline System Engineering Department, JTEKT Corporation, 1-5-3 Tado-cho, Takahama, Aichi 444-1323, Japan. Email: yoshiharu_inaguma@jtekt.co.jp

abstract.p: This article presents a practical approach to leakage flow analysing for various types of hydraulic pumps. In this study, the influence of pump-operating conditions such as operating pressures, pump speeds and oil temperature on the leakage flow characteristics is investigated and a mathematical model to calculate the leakage flow is proposed. Currently, an external gear, an internal gear or a vane pump is commonly used for an automatic transmission. These pumps have their own leakage flow characteristics, which depend not only on pump-operating conditions but also on structures and dimensions of the pumps. For various pumps having different constructions, the delivery pressure and the oil temperature differently affect the leakage flow characteristics and especially the delivery pressure also changes the clearances causing the leakage flow. A mathematical model for the leakage flow, which takes into account a change in the thickness of clearance according to the delivery pressure, represents accurately the actual leakage flow characteristics in various pumps. Also, it clarifies the influence of the pump-operating conditions on their leakage flow characteristics. In the external and internal gear pumps, the leakage flow would not approach zero due to an existence of the orifice flow leakage almost independent of the viscosity of oil, even at an extremely low oil temperature. This leakage flow influences significantly the volumetric efficiency at a low oil temperature in the gear pumps.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In an automatic transmission (AT) and a continuously variable transmission (CVT), an external gear pump1,2 and an internal gear pump2–7 have conventionally been used. These days, a balanced vane pump with a fixed-displacement is also used for CVT operated at the maximum pressure of 5 MPa because of its good volumetric efficiency.8–10 A hydraulic pump is necessary as a hydraulic power source for controlling the pressure to change the rotational speed of the output shaft and for lubrication, and then it operates across a broad range of oil temperatures as well as pressures and pump speeds in a vehicle. The volumetric efficiency as well as the mechanical efficiency to satisfy a required performance in a wide range of pump-operating conditions is an important factor to decide a type and specifications of pump.

For various pumps for AT and CVT of vehicles, the flow characteristics and the volumetric efficiencies as well as the pump-driving torque characteristics and the mechanical efficiencies have already been investigated.3,4 For the friction torque characteristics in various pumps, an improved mathematical model based on Wilson’s11,12 model was constructed and its effectiveness was demonstrated.13 Although the flow characteristics and the volumetric efficiencies in pumps for the transmissions were investigated,3,4 an analysis of the leakage flow in pumps is insufficient. For hydraulic pumps and motors, the mathematical models for the leakage flow dependent on the pressure were already proposed by Wilson11,12 and by Schlösser,14 and the flow characteristics were usefully analysed using their models. Both the models, however, are conceptual and they could not accurately represent the leakage flow characteristics in various types of pumps. Although the leakage flow characteristics in a vane pump15 or those in an internal gear pump16 were analysed, the influence of the pump-operating condition on the leakage flow was insufficiently investigated. For improving the volumetric efficiency, it is very important to analyse the components of leakage flow in various pumps.

In this article, a practical mathematical model for the leakage flow characteristics is introduced on the basis of the experimental data of the flow characteristics for an external gear, an internal gear and a balanced vane pumps. In the mathematical model, the change in the thickness of clearance according to the pump delivery pressure should be taken into account. Using the model, the leakage flow characteristics and the volumetric efficiency depending on the pump-operating conditions could be quantitatively analysed.

sec.title: Test pumps
sec.p:
In this study, three types of pumps, which are currently used for AT and CVT, were investigated. First, pump A is an external gear pump with involute gear teeth and has one driving gear and two driven ones. Although this pump is able to separately deliver oil to two passages under different delivery pressures as binary pumps, both the passages were communicated with an outlet port in the test pump. Therefore, the discharge flow of this pump was measured as a single pump having a double displacement process. The dimensions of pump A are shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Dimensions of test pump A (external gear pump).

Next, pump B is an internal gear pump widely used for AT and CVT, having an inner rotor with external gear teeth and an outer rotor with internal gear teeth. The tooth forms of the inner and the outer rotors are designed by combining two hypocycloidal curves. The inner rotor has one tooth less than the outer rotor and this pump has no crescent separator like a gerotor pump. Figure 2 shows the dimensions of pump B. Figure 2.
Dimensions of test pump B (internal gear pump).

Finally, pump C is a balanced vane pump with a fixed-displacement and composed of a cam ring with an elliptic inner bore, a rotor with a series of radially disposed vanes, a side plate, a body and a shaft. For Case Report test, two pumps (C-1 and C-2) were prepared. The side plate of pump C-1 has a smaller area pushed by the delivery pressure in the direction of the rotor compared with pump C-2. In addition, pump C-2 has a flow control unit to regulate the flow rate out of the pump to 433 × 10−6 m3/s (26 L/min) by bypassing an excess flow to the suction port despite variations in pump delivery flow due to changes in the pump speed. Their dimensions are shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Dimension of test pump C (balanced vane pump).

sec.title: Experimental apparatus
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows a schematic diagram of the experimental system for measuring flow rate out of the pump. The test pump was driven by a variable speed electric motor via pulleys and a belt. In the experimental system, oil delivered from the test pump returned through a flow-control valve to control the delivery pressure, a flow meter and then an oil temperature controller to an oil reservoir. The delivery pressure, pd, and the suction pressure, ps, were measured at an outlet and an inlet of the pump, respectively. The pressure differential across the pump Δp was defined by subtracting ps from pd. The oil temperature θ was measured at the pump outlet. The pump flow rate Q was measured twice with a gear type flow meter at the same operating condition. In this study, by setting the pump speed N and the oil temperature θ at a measuring point within ±10 min−1 and ±3℃, Q was measured in the process to increase pd and to decrease it again. During the measurement of Q, pd was maintained within ±0.02 MPa. After the measurement of Q for all pump speeds was completed, θ was changed. Figure 4.
Experimental system.

Through the entire test, the maximum value of the difference between the two measured values of Q at the same condition was 3.3 × 10−6 m3/s (0.2 L/min). Because this value was much smaller than the variations of Q with changing pump-operating condition, the mean value of the two measured values was adopted as Q in this study. For pump C-2, Q was measured in the region of N < 1600 min−1, in which the flow rate was not controlled. Table 1 presents the measuring condition of the flow rate for each pump. The hydraulic fluid is commercial mineral oil for CVT transmission, and its properties are given in Table 2. Table 1.
Operating conditions of test pumps.
A B C-1 C-2
Test pump External gear Internal gear Balanced vane Balanced vane
Pump speed, N (min−1) 600−4000 700−4000 1000−4000 600−1500
Pressure, Δp (MPa) 1−5 1−5 1−5 1−5
Oil temperature, θ (℃) 25, 80, 120 40, 80, 100 40, 80, 120 80, 120
Table 2.
Properties of oil.
Temperature, θ (℃) 25 40 60 80 100 120
Density, ρ (kg/m3) 843 834 822 810 798 786
Viscosity, μ (Pa·s) 0.0445 0.0254 0.0140 0.0085 0.0056 0.0040

sec.title: Experimental study and mathematical model on leakage flow
Leakage flow characteristics in various pumps
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the relationships between the pump flow rate Q and the pressure differencial Δp, denoted as pd − ps, at oil temperature θ = 80℃ for various pump speeds in the pumps shown in Figures 1 to 3. Excluding pump C-1, the decreases in Q against Δp for the other pumps are non-linear and their changing patterns differ. To investigate in detail, the leakage flow ΔQ was obtained by subtracting the actual pump flow rate Q from the ideal pump flow rate Qth (=VthN/60). Figure 5.
Relationships between Δp and Q.

For an accurate analysis of the leakage flow ΔQ, a correct determination of the theoretical displacement volume Vth of the test pump is important. However, it is not easy to determine Vth with accuracy.17 As Toet17 considered, Vth would be composed of the geometrical displacement volume and the dragged volume, and it is difficult to separate them. Therefore, Toet defined the sum of both the volumes as Vth and proposed a method to determine Vth from measurements of actual pump flow rate. In this study, Vth was experimentally determined according to Toet’s17 proposal, as shown in Appendix 2.

First, the influence of the pump speed on the leakage flow characteristics is investigated. Figure 6 shows the relationships between the pump speed N and the total leakage flow ΔQ measured at oil temperature θ of 80℃ for five kinds of Δp in pump A. On the ground that Vth determined from the measured flow rate includes the dragged volume due to the pump revolution, ΔQ would be independent of N, as expected. This characteristic is identical at other oil temperatures and the other pumps have the same results. The leakage flow, then, will be analysed independently of the pump speed. Figure 6.
Relationships between N and ΔQ (pump A).

Figure 7 shows Δp − ΔQ characteristics at N = 1000 min−1 for three oil temperatures in pump A. In this pump, the leakage flow ΔQ increases with an increase in oil temperature and in Δp. Strictly speaking, ΔQ is not proportional to Δp and the increasing rate of ΔQ becomes smaller and smaller with an increase in Δp. The changing rates of ΔQ for all oil temperatures are nearly equal, as described in detail later. Figure 7.
Relationships between Δp and ΔQ (pump A).

Figure 8 shows a comparison of Δp − ΔQ characteristics at N = 1000 min−1 and θ = 80℃ in all the tested pumps. Although the characteristic of pump C-2 is similar to that of pump A, pump B has the opposite character, namely the increasing rate of ΔQ against Δp becomes greater and greater. In pump C-1, ΔQ increases linearly with an increase in Δp. These tendencies are identical at other oil temperatures. As seen from these results, the changing patterns of ΔQ against Δp are different in various types of pumps. On the basis of the experimental data, a mathematical model of the leakage flow chatacteristics will be introduced. Figure 8.
Relationships between Δp and ΔQ for each pump.

sec.title: Mathematical model for leakage flow

list-item.p: Leakage flow through clearance between parallel discs, Δq1 The pressure-induced leakage flow Δq1 through the clearance between two fixed parallel discs shown in Figure 9(a) is expressed by the following equation15,18 (1)Δq1=αh13Δp12μln(r2/r1) In equation (1), α is 2π, when oil flows in all directions.

Leakage flow through clearance between parallel plates, Δq2 The pressure-induced leakage flow Δq2 through the clearance between two parallel plates shown in Figure 9(b) is expressed by the following equation14,15 (2)Δq2=bh23Δp12μL

Leakage flow as an orifice flow, Δq3 The leakage flow Δq3 at a gear tip shown in Figure 10(a) or (b) could be expressed by the following equation as an orifice flow14 (3)Δq3=Cfbh32Δp/ρ The width b is corresponding to the width of a gear (facewidth) in a gear pump and Cf is the orifice flow coefficient. Normally, an external gear pump is designed to separate the part of ps from that of pd by tips of two or more teeth on the opposite sides of engaged gears. However, it is expediently supposed that one tooth separates those parts. A pump fundamentally has three leakage flow components expressed by equations (1) to (3): two components proportional to Δp and one component proportional to the square root.Assuming that aforementioned leakage components arise at two or more parts in a pump, the total leakage flow calculated, ΔQ*, could be expressed as follows (4)ΔQ*=∑Δq1+∑Δq2+∑Δq3 In this study, a loss flow due to cavitation is assumed to be zero. Equation (4) would be effective for a pump with fixed-clearances, which are unaffected by the delivery pressure. However, a vane pump is usually designed so that its side plate is pushed by the delivery pressure in order to reduce the clearance between the rotor and the side plate (such as h1 and h2 in Figure 9) under high pressure conditions. In pumps including the vane pump, a deformation of a body or a cover due to the delivery pressure also changes the clearances h1 and h2. In an external or an internal gear pump, the unbalanced force acts on the gear due to a different pressure distribution around the gear. As a result, gears would move to change the gear tip clearance h3 in Figure 10. Therefore, the change in the thickness of the clearance according to the pressure differential should be considered for equations (1) to (3). In this study, a simple model in which the pressure differential affects linearly the thickness of clearance is introduced.

Consideration for change in thickness of clearance in equations (1) and (2) Supposing that the thickness of the clearance changes from h1 with a rate of ɛ1 against Δp, Δq1 can be developed as follows Δq1=α{h1(1+ɛ1Δp)}3Δp12μln(r2/r1)=αh13Δp12μln(r2/r1){1+3ɛ1Δp+3(ɛ1Δp)2+(ɛ1Δp)3} For simplification, by neglecting the third and fourth terms in the braces on the right-hand side this equation could be roughly approximated as follows (5)Δq1=A1μ(Δp+3ɛ1Δp2) where A1 = αh1312ln(r2/r1), and the value of ɛ1 becomes negative when the clearance becomes narrow with increasing Δp. Similarly, supposing that the thickness of the clearance changes from h2 with a rate of ɛ2 against Δp, Δq2 in equation (2) can be rewritten as the following equation (6)Δq2=A2μ(Δp+3ɛ2Δp2) where A2 = bh2312L, and the value of ɛ2 becomes negative when the clearance becomes narrow with increasing Δp.

Consideration for change in thickness of clearance in equation (3) Similarly again, supposing that the thickness of the clearance changes from h3 with a rate of ɛ3 against Δp, Δq3 in equation (3) can be rewritten as the following equation Δq3=Cfbh3(1+ɛ3Δp)2Δpρ=Cfbh3ρ2Δp(1+ɛ3Δp)=A3ρ(Δp1/2+ɛ3Δp3/2)(7) where A3 = 2Cfbh3 and the value of ɛ3 becomes negative when the clearance becomes narrow with increasing Δp.

caption.p: Configurations of clearances in a pump.

sec.p: Substituting equations (5) to (7) for equation (4) and arranging the result according to the exponent of Δp, ΔQ* can be expressed by the following equation (8)ΔQ*=CaμΔp+CbμΔp2+CcρΔp1/2+CdρΔp3/2 where Ca=∑A1+∑A2=112{∑αh13ln(r2/r1)+∑bh23L}Cb=∑3ɛ1A1+∑3ɛ2A2=14{∑ɛ1αh13ln(r2/r1)+∑ɛ2bh23L}Cc=∑A3=∑2Cfbh3Cd=∑ɛ3A3=∑2ɛ3Cfbh3

As a result, the total leakage flow ΔQ* could be composed of four components, in which the component proportional to Δp2 and that proportional to the 3 s power to Δp are also included. Wilson11,12 analysed the flow characteristics and the volumetric efficiencies in hydraulic pumps and motors using his mathematical model. His model for the leakage flow, however, has only the component proportional to Δp, i.e. the first term in equation (8) and his model can explain only the leakage flow characteristics of pump C-1 in Figure 8. Schlösser14 added the component of the orifice flow leakage proportional to the square root of Δp, which is corresponding to the third term in equation (8), to the Wilson’s model. His model, however, cannot explain the leakage flow characteristics of pump B in Figure 8, in which the increasing rate of the leakage flow against Δp becomes greater and greater with an increase in Δp. In contrast, the newly introduced model in this article enables to explain all characteristics shown in Figure 8. Then, the leakage flow characteristics in actual pumps are investigated using equation (8).

Denoting ΔQ* at θ1 and that at θ2 as ΔQ*|θ1 and ΔQ*|θ2, respectively, the difference between ΔQ*|θ1 and ΔQ*|θ2 is expressed by the following equation (9)ΔQ*|θ1-ΔQ*|θ2 =(1μ1-1μ2)(CaΔp+CbΔp2) +(1ρ1-1ρ2)(CcΔp1/2+CdΔp3/2) where ρ1 and ρ2 are ρ at θ1 and ρ at θ2, respectively.

In this study, the test was performed in a range of oil temperature from 25℃ to 120℃, and the changed value of ρ was within 3%. Because this rate is small, it could be supposed that ρ is constant in the test range. In contrast, the viscosity of oil drastically varies according to oil temperature and affects Reynolds number in an area of the orifice flow. Although Reynolds number might slightly affect the orifice flow coefficient Cf, it could be presumed to be constant. So, the second term on the right-hand side of equation (9) becomes zero, i.e. the leakage of the orifice flow is eliminated, and ΔQ*|θ1 − ΔQ*|θ2 becomes the difference between the viscous leakage flows through the clearances of the parallel discs/plates.
Hence equation (9) can be simplified as follows (10)ΔQ*|θ1-ΔQ*|θ2=(1μ1-1μ2)(CaΔp+CbΔp2)
Further, equation (10) is rewritten as the following equation (11)CaΔp+CbΔp2=ΔQ*|θ1-ΔQ*|θ21/μ1-1/μ2
Corresponding to the right-hand side of equation (11), λ is denoted using the actual leakage flows, ΔQ|θ1 at θ1 and ΔQ|θ2 at θ2, as the following equation (12)λ=ΔQ|θ1-ΔQ|θ21/μ1-1/μ2

Figure 11 shows the relationship between Δp and λ calculated form the experimental data of ΔQ|θ1 at θ1 and ΔQ|θ2 at θ2. In pumps A, B and C-1, λ is in direct proportion to Δp but pump C-2 has a parabolic change in λ against Δp. A linear change in λ means that Cb = 0 in equation (10), i.e. the thickness of the clearance is constant despite an increase in Δp. In the case of Cb = 0, Ca can be obtained by the following equation (13)Ca=λΔp Figure 11.
Relationships between Δp and λ for each pump.

In the case of Cb ≠ 0 in pump C-2, both Ca and Cb could be determined to simulate the change in λ against Δp by a least squares method. Using the values of Ca and Cb, the other constants Cc and Cd relating with the leakage of the orifice flow could be obtained according to the following procedure. Calculating the first and second terms on the right-hand side of equation (8) with the values of Ca and Cb, and subtracting the results from the actual leakage flow ΔQ, the sum of the third and fourth terms becomes the orifice flow leakage Δqo, as expressed by the following equation (14)Δqo=CcρΔp1/2+CdρΔp3/2

Figure 12 shows the relationship between Δp and Δqo for three oil temperatures in all the tested pumps. Pumps A (external gear) and B (internal gear) have Δqo increasing with an increase in Δp, and the results mean that these pumps have the leakage flow components of the orifice flow. The values of Δqo somewhat disperse but it could be considered that the Δp − Δqo characteristics are independent of oil temperature θ, i.e. the viscosity of oil. In contrast, Δqo is considered to be zero for various Δp and θ in the vane pumps C-1 and C-2. From this figure, the result of Cc = Cd = 0 is obtained for pumps C-1 and C-2. The values of Cc and Cd for pumps A and B could be determined to simulate the Δp − Δqo characteristics using a least squares method. All the constants of Ca to Cd for each test pump are presented in Table 3 and the results of Δqo calculated using these constants are indicated by the solid lines in Figure 12. The values of Cc and Cd depend on ρ. In this study, the values of ρ = 808 kg/m3 at θ = 80℃ are used. Using equation (8) and the values of Ca to Cd in Table 3, the total leakage flow ΔQ* can be calculated. Figure 12.
Estimated orifice flow leakage.
Table 3.
Values of Ca to Cd of test pumps.
A B C-1 C-2
Test pump External gear Internal gear Balanced vane Balanced vane
Ca (m3) 1.18 × 10−13 1.08 × 10−13 3.93 × 10−14 8.55 × 10−14
Cb (m5/N) 0 0 0 −4.50 × 10−21
Cc (m2) 2.87 × 10−7 5.14 × 10−9 0 0
Cd (m4/N) 0 5.98 × 10−14 0 0
Cc and Cd are calculated using value of ρ = 808 kg/cm3 at θ = 80℃.

Figure 13 shows the comparisons between ΔQ experimented and ΔQ* calculated for all the tested pumps. As seen from this figure, ΔQ* accurately agrees with ΔQ and the mathematical model can well represent the leakage flow characteristics for various pumps. Figure 13.
Comparison of leakage flows between experiment and calculation.

sec.title: Analysis of oil temperature influence on leakage flow and volumetric efficiency
sec.p: The leakage flow components in equation (8) are denoted from the left as ΔQa* = CaΔp/μ, ΔQb* = CbΔp2/μ, ΔQc* = CcΔp/ρ and ΔQd* = CdΔpΔp/ρ, respectively. They mean as follows: ΔQa*; the viscous flow leakage through the initial clearance of the parallel discs/plates, ΔQb*; the changed viscous flow leakage due to the change in the clearance of the parallel discs/plates, ΔQc*; the orifice flow leakage through the initial clearance and ΔQd*; the changed orifice flow leakage due to the change in the clearance.

Figure 14 shows the relationships between oil temperature θ and the total leakage flow ΔQ* and leakage flow components ΔQa* to ΔQd*, which are calculated for Δp = 5 MPa using the values of the constants in Table 3. Although the case of N = 1000 min−1 is shown in this figure, the results at the other pump speeds are identical because the leakage flow is independent of the pump speed. The calculated ΔQ* using the model agrees well with the measured ΔQ. Figure 14 clarifies the composition of the leakage flow components for each pump and the influence of the oil temperature θ on them. In pump A (external gear) shown in Figure 14(a), the leakage flow is composed of ΔQa* and ΔQc*. Because ΔQc* of the orifice flow leakage is considered to be almost independent of the viscosity of oil μ, it would not decrease with a decrease in θ. Pump B shown in Figure 14(b) adds ΔQd* almost independent of θ to the sum of ΔQa*and ΔQb*. The reason that pump B has ΔQd* would be derived from the ground that pump B has a much larger clearance between the outer circumference of the outer rotor and the body compared with the clearance between the shaft and the bush bearing of pump A. Figure 14.
Relationships between oil temperature and leakage flow for each pump.

The vane pumps C-1 and C-2 have no orifice flow leakage component. Pump C-1 with a smaller deformation of the side plate due to the delivery pressure pd has only ΔQa*, as shown in Figure 14(c). In contrast, pump C-2 shown in Figure 14(d) has not only ΔQa* but also ΔQb*. In pump C-2, the value of ΔQb* is negative because the clearance between the rotor and the side plate or the body decreases with an increase in pd. Namely, the total leakage flow of pump C-2 reduces from the fine solid line of ΔQa* to the thick solid line.

In addition, although the leakage flow characteristic of pump A seems to be similar to that of pump C-2 in Figure 8, the combination of the leakage flow components is different between these pumps. In pump C-2, ΔQb* decreases with a decrease in θ (an increase in μ) and approaches zero. However, ΔQc* in pump A would not decrease despite a decrease in θ. Through modelling the leakage flow characteristic, the components of the leakage flow are clarified and the result makes a suggestion for improving the volumetric efficiency.

Finally, the volumetric efficiencies for all of the tested pumps are compared at N = 1000 min−1 and Δp = 5 MPa. Figure 15 shows the relationships between the oil temperature θ and the volumetric efficiency. In this figure, the volumetric efficiency using ΔQ* calculated from the mathematical model is defined as ηv* = (Qth − ΔQ*)/Qth and that using the actual leakage flow ΔQ as ηv = (Qth − ΔQ)/Qth. The agreement of ηv* with ηv is excellent. In the tested pumps, the vane pumps have a higher ηv* than the other pumps. Although a difference in ηv* becomes small with a decrease in θ, ηv* may not approach 1.0 for an external or internal gear pump having the orifice flow leakage independent of μ. This fact in these pumps would be significant for improving ηv* at an extremely low oil temperature. Figure 15.
Comparison of volumetric efficiencies.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, a mathematical model for the leakage flow characteristic was constructed through an investigation of the leakage flow in an external gear, an internal gear and a balanced vane pumps. As a result of the analysis using the mathematical model, the following conclusions were drawn.

A pump having clearances in several sliding parts had fundamentally two types of leakage flows: a viscous flow and an orifice flow almost independent of the viscosity of oil. An internal gear pump had a leakage flow characteristic so that the increasing rate of the leakage flow became greater and greater with an increase in the pressure differential, which the Wilson’s and the Schlosser’s models were not able to represent. Assuming that the thickness of the clearance changes according to the pressure differential, this leakage flow characteristic also could be represented. The mathematical model with this consideration could clarify a composition of the leakage flows and represented well the actual leakage flow characteristics and the volumetric efficiency under various pump-operating conditions for various types of pumps.

When the clearance between two parallel discs or plates decreased with increasing the pressure differential, at first sight, the leakage flow characteristic seemed to be similar to that including an orifice flow leakage through a fixed clearance. However, these were different in dependence on the viscosity of oil.

In the external or internal gear pump, because of an existence of the orifice flow leakage almost independent of the viscosity of oil, the leakage flow would never become nearly zero, even at an extremely low oil temperature.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Appendix 2
sec.p:
As an example, the determination of the theoretical pump displacement volume Vth of pump A is described. Figure 16(a) shows the relationships between the pump speed N and the actual pump flow rate Q at θ = 120℃ for various pressure differential Δp. Through a linear approximation of the relationship between N and Q at each Δp, a gradient β of N − Q line is estimated. Similarly, values of β at another θ can be obtained. From the relation of Vth = 60β, Vth for various Δp at each θ can be calculated. Arranging these values with respect to Δp, as shown in Figure 16(b), the values at Δp = 0 are extrapolated from a linear approximation for three kinds of θ. The mean value is adopted as the pump displacement Vth for pump A. Through the same procedure, Vth is determined for the other pumps. Figure 16.
Determination of theoretical pump displacement (pump A).
